abstract: Editorial warns black lung disease, lethal hazard for coal miners, appears to be on the rise again, with 7,400 new claims expected in 2014; contends main obstacle to fair and prompt compensation for those afflicted with disease are the batteries of well-financed doctors and lawyers hired by mining companies eager to avoid paying roughly $1,000 a month they would owe disabled miners.
lead_paragraph: The disease appears to be on the rise again, and miners face addition distress over legalistic requirements that deny them benefits for years.

headline.main: Miners Battle Black Lung, and Bureaucracy
